current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To prohibit certain foreign assistance to the Government of Egypt as a result of the July 3, 2013,
			 military coup d'état.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

header.#text:
Foreign
			 assistance restrictions in response to Egyptian military coup d'état

text.#text:
On June 30, 2012,
			 Mohamed Morsi was elected President of Egypt in elections that were
			 certified
			 as free and fair by the Egyptian Presidential Election Commission and the

On July 3, 2013,
			 the military of Egypt removed the democratically elected President of
			 Egypt,
			 arrested his supporters, and suspended the Constitution of Egypt. These
			 actions
			 fit the definition of a military coup d'état.

On August 14, 2013, Egyptian security forces killed over 600 protestors in the dispersal of a
			 demonstration in Rabaa, Egypt.

Since the July 2013 military coup d'état, the Egyptian military and security officials are
			 estimated to have killed more than 1,000 Egyptian citizen protestors.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that conditioned economic assistance to the  Government of Egypt
			 on concrete and measurable actions to restore democracy to the citizens of
			 Egypt.

approved the transfer of 10 AH–64 Apache Helicopters and
			 $650,000,000 in financial aid to the military-controlled Government of
			 Egypt.

text.#text:
On April 28, 2014, a court in Egypt sentenced 683 Egyptian citizens to death for protests in the
			 town of Edwa, Egypt, following a five-minute hearing that was not long
			 enough to recite the full names of the accused.

On May 5, 2014, Former Army Chief Abdul Fattah al-Sisi, who led Egyptian military forces in the
			 coup d’état against a ruling party that was elected with 51.7 percent of
			 the vote, said on Egyptian television that, if elected, the previous
			 ruling political party would

On May 6, 2014, a court in Egypt banned members of the National Democratic Party from participating
			 in any Presidential, parliamentary, or local elections.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the
			 United States is legally prohibited from providing foreign assistance to
			 any
			 country whose duly elected head of government is deposed by a military
			 coup
			 d'état, or removed in such a way that the military plays a decisive
			 role.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 7008 of the Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related
			 Programs Act, 2012
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Act, 2012/s:7008

text.#text:
The United States
			 has suspended aid to countries that have undergone military coups d'état
			 in the
			 past, including the Ivory Coast, the Central African Republic, Thailand,
			 Mali,
			 Fiji, and Honduras.

header.#text:
Foreign
			 assistance to the Government of Egypt
